Marks, III''' is the [[Mayor]] of the City of [[Tallahassee, Florida]]. He is Tallahassee's fifth African-American mayor but the first to be elected, and won his bid for a third term in the 2010 elections. He received his [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] degree in 1969 from the [[Florida State University]] School of Business and his [[Juris Doctorate]] in 1972 from the [[Florida State University College of Law]]. The Mayor faces a series of allegations for questionable dealings involving city contracts. According to the Tallahassee Democrat, the Federal Bureau of Investigation is looking into the matter.<ref name="wctv">WCTV [http://www.wctv.tv/home/headlines/Corruption_in__118832254.html Corruption in Tallahassee]</ref><ref name="tallahassee democrat">Tallahassee Democrat: [http://www.tallahassee.com/article/20110422/NEWS01/104220324/FBI-probes-city-purchasing-policy FBI Probes city purchasing policy]</ref>
Marks served eight years on the [[Florida Public Service Commission]] <ref>[http://www.psc.state.fl.us/ Florida Public Service Commission]</ref> (FPSC) and spent the last two as its Chairman, after being appointed in 1979 by Governor [[Bob Graham]]. He served on the FPSC during the divestiture of [[AT&T]] and was instrumental in the implementation of the [[Federal Public Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act|Federal Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act]] (PURPA). Before being appointed, he served as an [[Administrative Law|Administrative Law Judge]] on the Commission. He is a partner in the Tallahassee -based Marks & Marks law firm. He has been an adjunct professor at FSU's College of Law, teaching utility regulatory law and a faculty member of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners' <ref>[http://www.naruc.org/ National Association of Regulatory Commissioners]</ref> utility rate school. Member of [[Omega Psi Phi]] Fraternity.
He is married to Jane Marks and has a son, John Marks, IV.
